result.execSummary:
The defendant Chad A. Wampole was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Retail Theft - Intentionally Take >$500 - $5000) [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.50(1m)(b).
  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Portage County Clerk of Circuit Court

miscConds.notes:
Pay costs including the DNA surcharge. 
  If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.
Obtain and maintain full time employment or school.

Do not have direct/indirect contact with the co-defendants: Jahn Tinglum, Leah Luedtke, Shawnya Goetz. 
Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription. 
Do not possess any drug paraphernalia. 
Do not associate with any persons possessing or consuming illegal controlled substances.
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.
Maintain absolute sobriety with regards to alcohol and illegal drugs unless they are prescribed.

Comply with any treatment deemed necessary by the agent. 
Sign all necessary releases so that the agent can monitor doctors and what is being prescribed. 
Provide DNA, if not provided.
(No restitution - all items have been recovered)
Transfer of probation to county of home residence.
Court orders return of the cell phone.
**Amended to add: Prescription medication should all come from the same pharmacy.**

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

supervisions.notes: *Eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program and Substance Abuse Program

superMiscConds.notes:
*Pay court costs that were previously ordered and not paid, including DNA Surcharge
*If any fines, costs & restitution remain outstanding at the end of the confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining balances shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 50% of gross.

*Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.
*Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription. 
*Do not possess any drug paraphernalia.

*Fill all prescriptions from a single pharmacy
*Sign all necessary releases of information
*Comply with AODA assessment or to have another AODA and comply with all treatment recommendations from assessment

Defendant Chad A. Wampole in court with attorney Jerod Barkley. Defendant Chad A. Wampole in custody. Daniel R. Hess appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

10:31 AM Court calls case.

Matter is set for a sentencing hearing after probation was revoked.

State has complied with victim notification statutes.

Atty Barkley also received a copy of the packet, Defendant has seen a part of the packet.
Defendant wishes to go forward with the hearing today.
Court is willing to adjourn this for the Defendant to read entire packet.
Defendant still wishes to go forward.

Atty Hess addresses the Court, concurs with the recommendations in the packet.

Atty Barkley addresses the Court. 359 days credit.

Court questions Defendant regarding AODA assessment and lack of fine payments. Defendant replies.

Court addresses the parties, has a number of factors to consider to determine sentencing.

BY THE COURT:
Count 1:
Determinate Prison Sentence for 28 Months

359 Days Credit

Conditions:
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment
Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription 
Do not possess any drug paraphernalia

50% of any monies from prison account can be used for payment of court costs
Comply with AODA Assessment or to have another AODA and comply wiht all treatment recommendations from assessment

Written explanation of Determinate Sentence will be provided to Defendant.

Defendant Chad A. Wampole in court with attorney Jerod Albert Barkley. Defendant Chad A. Wampole in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
  
Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of:  Counts 1 & 2: NO CONTEST

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorney stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty of Counts 1 & 2.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
Counts 3 & 4 are dismissed and read-in. 
Court orders PSI. 
PSI to be completed with copies forwarded to counse to prepare for sentencing arguments no later than 11/24/14.

Defendant Chad A. Wampole in court with attorney Jerod A Barkley. Veronica F Isherwood appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
1:33 p.m.  case is called and appearances stated on the record.
14CF79
This is a plea hearing.
Attorney Barkley states there is no plea agreement.  Defendant is still undecided.
Attorney Barkley states there is a motion for a bond hearing.
There was a cash bond of $2500 set but the defendant is not able to post any money.  Defendant was in the process of preparing a tax return when he was arrested.
Anticipation of probation in this matter.
ADA makes statement re: bond indicating it is an appropriate amount.  Defendant has quite a list of previous convictions.  Requests denial of motion.  
Attorney Barkley replies to the states position.  
This court has not set the original bond - Judge Eagon had set the bond.  Indicates there is a lengthy list of convictions.  Court finds the bond amounts is appropriate.  

BTC:
